人造綠葉吸收CO2 生成燃氣

04 Nov 2019, 13:58

【新唐人北京時間2019年11月04日訊】近期發表在《自然-材料》（Nature Materials）雜誌上的研究稱，造出一種「人工綠葉」設備，通過陽光、二氧化碳和水生成氣體燃料。研究者稱這是零碳排放太陽能技術的新高度，在製造合成汽油方面有很好的前景。
這個設備模擬植物通過陽光把二氧化碳變成養分的光合作用過程，由兩片人造葉子——兩個光吸收器，結合鈷元素製造的催化劑組成，在有陽光和水的環境下，生成氫氣和一氧化碳的混合氣體，它是製造燃料、藥品、塑料和肥料等產品都需要用到的工業原料。
主要作者之一劍橋大學化學系教授賴斯納（Erwin Reisner）介紹說，將設備浸在水中，一個光吸收器利用催化劑產生氧氣；另一個通過化學反應將二氧化碳變成一氧化碳和氫氣，產生混合氣。
其它一些同類設備使用硅或燃料敏化材料，這種設備使用的是鈣鈦礦光吸收器，提供高光電壓和電流為化學反應提供能源；另外其催化劑使用的鈷材料比其它同類設備使用的鉑和銀廉價，而且其催生一氧化碳的性能也更好。
賴斯納說，合成氣是液體燃料的重要原料基礎，「現在要先生成合成氣之後產生液體燃料，下一步，我們打算從二氧化碳和水直接造出液體燃料。」
合成汽油的開發具有重要意義，現在電力只能提供世界能源需求量的25%，「重型運輸、船舶、航天領域對液體燃料的需求很大。」
研究人員還說，這個設備對陽光需要不高，在陰天和雨天也可以工作。
──轉自《大紀元》

Artificial green leaves absorb CO2 to generate gas

04 Nov 2019, 13:58

[New Tang Dynasty, Beijing, November 4, 2019] A recent study published in the journal Nature Materials said that an "artificial green leaf" device was created to generate gaseous fuel through sunlight, carbon dioxide and water. Researchers say this is a new height in zero-carbon solar technology and has good prospects for making synthetic gasoline.
This device simulates the photosynthesis process in which plants turn carbon dioxide into nutrients through sunlight. It consists of two artificial leaves, two light absorbers, a catalyst made of cobalt, which produces hydrogen and carbon monoxide in a sunny and watery environment. Mixed gas, which is an industrial raw material used in the manufacture of fuels, pharmaceuticals, plastics and fertilizers.
One of the lead authors, Erwin Reisner, a professor of chemistry at the University of Cambridge, said that the device is immersed in water, one light absorber uses a catalyst to generate oxygen, and the other chemically reacts carbon dioxide into carbon monoxide and hydrogen to produce a mixture.
Other devices of the same type use silicon or fuel sensitizers that use a perovskite optical absorber that provides high photovoltage and current to provide energy for chemical reactions. In addition, the catalyst uses cobalt compared to other similar devices. It is cheaper than silver, and its carbon monoxide performance is better.
Resner said that syngas is an important raw material basis for liquid fuels. "Now we want to produce liquid fuel after syngas. Next, we intend to make liquid fuel directly from carbon dioxide and water."
The development of synthetic gasoline is of great significance. Now, electricity can only provide 25% of the world's energy demand. "The demand for liquid fuel in heavy transportation, shipbuilding and aerospace is very high."
The researchers also said that the device does not require high sunlight and can work on cloudy and rainy days.
